As to continue https://class.coursera.org/organalysis-003/forum/thread?thread_id=176 ' Kateryna Tkachenko · 6 hours ago There are frequent mistakes in trying to change culture: 1. Beginning with a vision, but failing to put in place the management tools that will cement the behavioral changes in place. 2. Overuse of the power tools of coercion and underuse of leadership tools. 3. Beginning with power tools even before a clear vision or story of the future is in place. Many of you have experiences and opinions on this. Let's share thoughts. ' ---- Before talking about organizational culture and even changing it ... it’s better to define what it is... more clearly! My opinion is that it's mostly the habits. Habits to do things in a specific manner, establish relationships, manage people, welcome each other, and negotiate. Habits sure come with people. Do we really want to change people? I think not. Personally I liked the lecture 3 of the week one materials. In case example there was somehow common vision of the future and it's benefits has been built first before. Second, and the most important they’ve been solving real problem in environment – solving a task for society. Then after three years of focused work organization culture really changed, but still (as reported) was fragile. Three years past. Then why so fragile? J I think that because to the end of the third year they didn’t really find a final path of how to really solve external problem of society. That’s why there were attempts to switch back to habits proven for centuries (including traditional style of education). In other words they’ve built a new model, but as they tried to spread it (culture) out, the new model appeared not so mature to solve external problem as they (principal and faculty) had seen from the inside. I think that’s why. So, is it easy to change organizational culture? The first question is why to change? Isn’t organizational culture an instrument for organization to something good outside (perform it’s mission for example)? And isn’t good organizational structure a reward for organizations making goods things outside and really solving social and other types of problems outside? In other words why to want something better for yourself if not doing something that is required for others (environment)?

Hi David, you have said a lot in the above and it struck a nerve. I would like to try to respond while also formulating why it is so difficult to change organisational culture in my opinion. In my view we are all learning how to deal with all these new forms of technology and my guess is that in the future several 'types of culture' will develop in how (and when) we will use the communication technology available to us for instance in organisations and also in various social settings. These cultures may vary hugely though from one playground to the next, and certainly from one organisation to the next. For any culture to change it often takes a clash between at least two underlying norms, and it takes one or more change agents (people) that take action to remedy the clash. Three things might be the outcome when norms clash: norm A is rejected and norm B prevails; norm B is rejected and norm A prevails; or norm C (a new norm) develops somehow incorporating the two cultural norms so they do not clash anymore. In your example of say the playground at least two cultural norms might be clashing for a few or maybe even most people present A) be polite and sociable in company (in this case the other parents at the playground) and B) answer when somebody speaks to you (some of us feel the messages coming in on a mobile device 'have to be answered'). For some reason a lot of people give preference to answering/interacting with others via devices to communicating with other parents at playgrounds, however that does not mean all of these people have rejected norm A. They may simply find it easier, because they feel a little intimidated by others busy looking at their devices (possibly because of a third norm might be at play 'don't interrupt people when they are clearly busy'). If a critical mass feels it would actually be nicer/better/more fun to talk to the other parents it still takes at least one change agent to 'stand up' and start looking for ways to generate change whether this is on the playground or within an organisation. Sometimes change happens over night, however that usually takes a dramatic incident, like a colleague who died because safety measure are routinely not applied (norm A being imposed by the company 'the safety rules have to be applied' and norm B being 'I can bend the rules when I think it is safe enough, the company does not need to prescribe every move I make'). In such a case one or more change agents might 'stand up' and then the 'safety culture' might change overnight to the company rules. In most cases however the situation is similar to your example at the playground, it takes at least one parent who decides to make an effort to talk to other parents (or come up with a plan of organised change, however that is probably unlikely at the playground). Gradually more and more parents might start following that example, however some parents will resist or even be rude when someone interrupts them. If that first change agent 'fails' at the first attempt or two, they might give up trying. And for some reason a lot people simply do not want to be change agents as they are afraid of what others might think of them so they might not jump up and help the change agent right away. In short, unless there is a dramatic incident (like the death mentioned or the invention of internet 2.0) generating change often takes hard work and dealing with resistance (and a lot of guts and a bit of charisma will certainly help). And then like mentioned in the lecture, the outcome of an effort to change things might be very different from what you expected. The only thing I know for sure is that if you want change, you need to act and except that you might fail trying.

The places I've seen where there is the most resistance to changes in org culture are also the places with the worst org culture - and I think the reason for that is strongly related. Where I've seen the worst culture, there's a high rate of turnover, high stress, lack of clarity, poor communication, some roles with lots of responsibility but little authority, some roles with lots of authority but very little responsibility...all things that led to people feeling insecure about their roles, unsure about the possibility for success, and defensive. People who are pouring energy into doing their jobs while accommodating or working around a poor org culture don't have a huge amount of energy left to commit to change. In that climate, it's also difficult to assume that the very few people within that org who benefit from that culture are working in good faith to change it - particularly since there may be a historical string of failed attempts. All of that said, I think that it is possible to change an organizational culture; it's crucial to expect that the change will take work and that the work of creating a good, sustainable, and effective culture is ongoing and takes near-universal participation. Leadership needs to model that work and to actively support the time and energy it takes; they also must address members of the org who refuse to support the change - I've seen efforts fail simply because all but one person engaged...but then leadership's response was to ask everyone *except* the person resisting the change to 'work around' the person resisting it. So the new culture became a pretense, because everyone had to continue to perform all of the old culture behind the scenes. tl;dr - In my opinion, people need to trust that their work to change the culture will have value, and that they have somewhere steady/secure to stand *while* their work culture changes. And the work of cultural improvement must have 360 degree buy-in.

Hi Aleksei, First, we need to define what is organisational culture. In my opinion, organisational culture is an important set of beliefs, rules (implied and/or written) and practices that smoothly assists in the organisation's daily operations and are either formally or informally adopted by the participants. The organisation establishes its culture through mutual agreements that those rules, beliefs and practices are beneficial, effective and crucial, and as such the culture is deeply ingrained within the organisation and its participants. Organisational culture can be said to be the way of living and working in the organisation and hence, changing it might induce unnecessary disruption to the daily lives and operations. An example of Organisational Culture could be its belief of contributing back to society via volunteerism or caring for the environment by adopting green measures. S Culture is not a fixed, written-in-stone and inflexible set of commandments but rather it is flexible and constantly evolving to meet the needs of the organisation's participants. Is it easy to change? That really depends on the participants' resistance to change, as well as the direction, consequence and effort required of the proposed change. Changes to the culture could be introduced if the head of the organisation changes (to provide a different direction according to his/her beliefs) or when participants provided well-described, explained and irrefutable proposals for the new change. Alternatively, pressures from the external environment or even within the organisation could force the organisation to review and revise its culture. It should be noted that organisational culture should not be confused with corporate social responsibility, in which the latter comes under the former. Some organisations may or not practice corporate social responsibility depending on their size, nature and culture. And, according to my experience, corporate social responsibility activities are often the product of public relations efforts. Hence, positive organisational culture is a tool employed to do good and reap the benefits for both internal and external parties. If you are asking for an organisation to do good for others at its own expense without it reaping any form of tangible or intangible rewards (monetary or improvement to image), the organisation is most likely be unwilling to participate and the enthusiastic participant(s) might have to engage in the activity alone without the resources and support from the organisation. Organisations want to do good for others and itself too.

Hi David, you have said a lot in the above and it struck a nerve. I would like to try to respond while also formulating why it is so difficult to change organisational culture in my opinion. In my view we are all learning how to deal with all these new forms of technology and my guess is that in the future several 'types of culture' will develop in how (and when) we will use the communication technology available to us for instance in organisations and also in various social settings. These cultures may vary hugely though from one playground to the next, and certainly from one organisation to the next. For any culture to change it often takes a clash between at least two underlying norms, and it takes one or more change agents (people) that take action to remedy the clash. Three things might be the outcome when norms clash: norm A is rejected and norm B prevails; norm B is rejected and norm A prevails; or norm C (a new norm) develops somehow incorporating the two cultural norms so they do not clash anymore. In your example of say the playground at least two cultural norms might be clashing for a few or maybe even most people present A) be polite and sociable in company (in this case the other parents at the playground) and B) answer when somebody speaks to you (some of us feel the messages coming in on a mobile device 'have to be answered'). For some reason a lot of people give preference to answering/interacting with others via devices to communicating with other parents at playgrounds, however that does not mean all of these people have rejected norm A. They may simply find it easier, because they feel a little intimidated by others busy looking at their devices (possibly because of a third norm might be at play 'don't interrupt people when they are clearly busy'). If a critical mass feels it would actually be nicer/better/more fun to talk to the other parents it still takes at least one change agent to 'stand up' and start looking for ways to generate change whether this is on the playground or within an organisation. Sometimes change happens over night, however that usually takes a dramatic incident, like a colleague who died because safety measure are routinely not applied (norm A being imposed by the company 'the safety rules have to be applied' and norm B being 'I can bend the rules when I think it is safe enough, the company does not need to prescribe every move I make'). In such a case one or more change agents might 'stand up' and then the 'safety culture' might change overnight to the company rules. In most cases however the situation is similar to your example at the playground, it takes at least one parent who decides to make an effort to talk to other parents (or come up with a plan of organised change, however that is probably unlikely at the playground). Gradually more and more parents might start following that example, however some parents will resist or even be rude when someone interrupts them. If that first change agent 'fails' at the first attempt or two, they might give up trying. And for some reason a lot people simply do not want to be change agents as they are afraid of what others might think of them so they might not jump up and help the change agent right away. In short, unless there is a dramatic incident (like the death mentioned or the invention of internet 2.0) generating change often takes hard work and dealing with resistance (and a lot of guts and a bit of charisma will certainly help). And then like mentioned in the lecture, the outcome of an effort to change things might be very different from what you expected. The only thing I know for sure is that if you want change, you need to act and except that you might fail trying.

The places I've seen where there is the most resistance to changes in org culture are also the places with the worst org culture - and I think the reason for that is strongly related. Where I've seen the worst culture, there's a high rate of turnover, high stress, lack of clarity, poor communication, some roles with lots of responsibility but little authority, some roles with lots of authority but very little responsibility...all things that led to people feeling insecure about their roles, unsure about the possibility for success, and defensive. People who are pouring energy into doing their jobs while accommodating or working around a poor org culture don't have a huge amount of energy left to commit to change. In that climate, it's also difficult to assume that the very few people within that org who benefit from that culture are working in good faith to change it - particularly since there may be a historical string of failed attempts. All of that said, I think that it is possible to change an organizational culture; it's crucial to expect that the change will take work and that the work of creating a good, sustainable, and effective culture is ongoing and takes near-universal participation. Leadership needs to model that work and to actively support the time and energy it takes; they also must address members of the org who refuse to support the change - I've seen efforts fail simply because all but one person engaged...but then leadership's response was to ask everyone *except* the person resisting the change to 'work around' the person resisting it. So the new culture became a pretense, because everyone had to continue to perform all of the old culture behind the scenes. tl;dr - In my opinion, people need to trust that their work to change the culture will have value, and that they have somewhere steady/secure to stand *while* their work culture changes. And the work of cultural improvement must have 360 degree buy-in.

Hi Aleksei, First, we need to define what is organisational culture. In my opinion, organisational culture is an important set of beliefs, rules (implied and/or written) and practices that smoothly assists in the organisation's daily operations and are either formally or informally adopted by the participants. The organisation establishes its culture through mutual agreements that those rules, beliefs and practices are beneficial, effective and crucial, and as such the culture is deeply ingrained within the organisation and its participants. Organisational culture can be said to be the way of living and working in the organisation and hence, changing it might induce unnecessary disruption to the daily lives and operations. An example of Organisational Culture could be its belief of contributing back to society via volunteerism or caring for the environment by adopting green measures. S Culture is not a fixed, written-in-stone and inflexible set of commandments but rather it is flexible and constantly evolving to meet the needs of the organisation's participants. Is it easy to change? That really depends on the participants' resistance to change, as well as the direction, consequence and effort required of the proposed change. Changes to the culture could be introduced if the head of the organisation changes (to provide a different direction according to his/her beliefs) or when participants provided well-described, explained and irrefutable proposals for the new change. Alternatively, pressures from the external environment or even within the organisation could force the organisation to review and revise its culture. It should be noted that organisational culture should not be confused with corporate social responsibility, in which the latter comes under the former. Some organisations may or not practice corporate social responsibility depending on their size, nature and culture. And, according to my experience, corporate social responsibility activities are often the product of public relations efforts. Hence, positive organisational culture is a tool employed to do good and reap the benefits for both internal and external parties. If you are asking for an organisation to do good for others at its own expense without it reaping any form of tangible or intangible rewards (monetary or improvement to image), the organisation is most likely be unwilling to participate and the enthusiastic participant(s) might have to engage in the activity alone without the resources and support from the organisation. Organisations want to do good for others and itself too.

Three things might be the outcome when norms clash: norm A is rejected and norm B prevails; norm B is rejected and norm A prevails; or norm C (a new norm) develops somehow incorporating the two cultural norms so they do not clash anymore. In your example of say the playground at least two cultural norms might be clashing for a few or maybe even most people present A) be polite and sociable in company (in this case the other parents at the playground) and B) answer when somebody speaks to you (some of us feel the messages coming in on a mobile device 'have to be answered'). Hi David, you have said a lot in the above and it struck a nerve. I would like to try to respond while also formulating why it is so difficult to change organisational culture in my opinion. In my view we are all learning how to deal with all these new forms of technology and my guess is that in the future several 'types of culture' will develop in how (and when) we will use the communication technology available to us for instance in organisations and also in various social settings. These cultures may vary hugely though from one playground to the next, and certainly from one organisation to the next. For any culture to change it often takes a clash between at least two underlying norms, and it takes one or more change agents (people) that take action to remedy the clash. Three things might be the outcome when norms clash: norm A is rejected and norm B prevails; norm B is rejected and norm A prevails; or norm C (a new norm) develops somehow incorporating the two cultural norms so they do not clash anymore. In your example of say the playground at least two cultural norms might be clashing for a few or maybe even most people present A) be polite and sociable in company (in this case the other parents at the playground) and B) answer when somebody speaks to you (some of us feel the messages coming in on a mobile device 'have to be answered'). For some reason a lot of people give preference to answering/interacting with others via devices to communicating with other parents at playgrounds, however that does not mean all of these people have rejected norm A. They may simply find it easier, because they feel a little intimidated by others busy looking at their devices (possibly because of a third norm might be at play 'don't interrupt people when they are clearly busy'). If a critical mass feels it would actually be nicer/better/more fun to talk to the other parents it still takes at least one change agent to 'stand up' and start looking for ways to generate change whether this is on the playground or within an organisation. Sometimes change happens over night, however that usually takes a dramatic incident, like a colleague who died because safety measure are routinely not applied (norm A being imposed by the company 'the safety rules have to be applied' and norm B being 'I can bend the rules when I think it is safe enough, the company does not need to prescribe every move I make'). In such a case one or more change agents might 'stand up' and then the 'safety culture' might change overnight to the company rules. In most cases however the situation is similar to your example at the playground, it takes at least one parent who decides to make an effort to talk to other parents (or come up with a plan of organised change, however that is probably unlikely at the playground). Gradually more and more parents might start following that example, however some parents will resist or even be rude when someone interrupts them. If that first change agent 'fails' at the first attempt or two, they might give up trying. And for some reason a lot people simply do not want to be change agents as they are afraid of what others might think of them so they might not jump up and help the change agent right away. In short, unless there is a dramatic incident (like the death mentioned or the invention of internet 2.0) generating change often takes hard work and dealing with resistance (and a lot of guts and a bit of charisma will certainly help). And then like mentioned in the lecture, the outcome of an effort to change things might be very different from what you expected. The only thing I know for sure is that if you want change, you need to act and except that you might fail trying.

Whatever organization exists, it has participants who are benefiting from the organization's current configuration. The longer that configuration continues, the more participants who benefit from the current configuration tend to have influence and power (both formal and informal). I would posit that any change, even change that comes about to better achieve the org's stated goals, or to adapt to new environmental pressures, nonetheless challenges that status quo. Participants who benefit from the current configuration (and therefore tend to have influence) will tend to resist change that could disrupt their current status. Benefits to the current configuration can also be expanded to think about individuals who are simply comfortable with the status quo = I.E. they enjoy their current job, and are not invested enough in whatever is motivating the change to want to disrupt their particular situation. Since change tends to require more work to enact, past behaviors will also always tend be easier than the new proposal.

The places I've seen where there is the most resistance to changes in org culture are also the places with the worst org culture - and I think the reason for that is strongly related. Where I've seen the worst culture, there's a high rate of turnover, high stress, lack of clarity, poor communication, some roles with lots of responsibility but little authority, some roles with lots of authority but very little responsibility...all things that led to people feeling insecure about their roles, unsure about the possibility for success, and defensive. People who are pouring energy into doing their jobs while accommodating or working around a poor org culture don't have a huge amount of energy left to commit to change. In that climate, it's also difficult to assume that the very few people within that org who benefit from that culture are working in good faith to change it - particularly since there may be a historical string of failed attempts. All of that said, I think that it is possible to change an organizational culture; it's crucial to expect that the change will take work and that the work of creating a good, sustainable, and effective culture is ongoing and takes near-universal participation. Leadership needs to model that work and to actively support the time and energy it takes; they also must address members of the org who refuse to support the change - I've seen efforts fail simply because all but one person engaged...but then leadership's response was to ask everyone *except* the person resisting the change to 'work around' the person resisting it. So the new culture became a pretense, because everyone had to continue to perform all of the old culture behind the scenes. tl;dr - In my opinion, people need to trust that their work to change the culture will have value, and that they have somewhere steady/secure to stand *while* their work culture changes. And the work of cultural improvement must have 360 degree buy-in.

Hi Aleksei, First, we need to define what is organisational culture. In my opinion, organisational culture is an important set of beliefs, rules (implied and/or written) and practices that smoothly assists in the organisation's daily operations and are either formally or informally adopted by the participants. The organisation establishes its culture through mutual agreements that those rules, beliefs and practices are beneficial, effective and crucial, and as such the culture is deeply ingrained within the organisation and its participants. Organisational culture can be said to be the way of living and working in the organisation and hence, changing it might induce unnecessary disruption to the daily lives and operations. An example of Organisational Culture could be its belief of contributing back to society via volunteerism or caring for the environment by adopting green measures. S Culture is not a fixed, written-in-stone and inflexible set of commandments but rather it is flexible and constantly evolving to meet the needs of the organisation's participants. Is it easy to change? That really depends on the participants' resistance to change, as well as the direction, consequence and effort required of the proposed change. Changes to the culture could be introduced if the head of the organisation changes (to provide a different direction according to his/her beliefs) or when participants provided well-described, explained and irrefutable proposals for the new change. Alternatively, pressures from the external environment or even within the organisation could force the organisation to review and revise its culture. It should be noted that organisational culture should not be confused with corporate social responsibility, in which the latter comes under the former. Some organisations may or not practice corporate social responsibility depending on their size, nature and culture. And, according to my experience, corporate social responsibility activities are often the product of public relations efforts. Hence, positive organisational culture is a tool employed to do good and reap the benefits for both internal and external parties. If you are asking for an organisation to do good for others at its own expense without it reaping any form of tangible or intangible rewards (monetary or improvement to image), the organisation is most likely be unwilling to participate and the enthusiastic participant(s) might have to engage in the activity alone without the resources and support from the organisation. Organisations want to do good for others and itself too.

With business and the market place forever changing, the far sighted organisation will always retain an open mind on the issues and actions of organisational change. They do so if only to adapt and respond to what is happening across their industry environments. From a leadership perspective the successful implementation of ‘change’ is seen as an essential mechanism that closes the gap between thought and action and strategy and implementation. The critical adjustments made by the organisation to organisational structure, operations and processes are all carried out in order to align the business activities to the market, as well as among other considerations to support the need to successfully implement strategy, improve efficiency, and secure investor returns. In order for such ambitions to be reached there is the crucial issue of perception to consider. Leadership perceptions are known to impact on employee behaviour in both a positive and negative manner, and thus can influence and determine the culture of the organisation. Perceptions also impact on the strategy-making process, seen by the weight of consideration and importance that leadership place on potential strategic ambitions. It therefore comes as no surprise that the individual and collective perceptions fostered by senior executives do have a significant impact on how the organisational change process is managed, and what the final outcome will look like. In addition to leadership perception, we also need to look closely at available leadership competency. Competency here refers to the characteristics and measurable patterns of behaviour, knowledge, situation awareness and skill that leadership can contribute and deliver to the organisation change process. The available breadth and depth of executive competency will determine the height of the ‘barrier of complexity ’ that routinely needs to be scaled by the company executives and staff in order to manage the change management programme to a satisfactory conclusion as well as dictating the pace at which the change progress can be implemented.

For any culture to change it often takes a clash between at least two underlying norms, and it takes one or more change agents (people) that take action to remedy the clash. Three things might be the outcome when norms clash: norm A is rejected and norm B prevails; norm B is rejected and norm A prevails; or norm C (a new norm) develops somehow incorporating the two cultural norms so they do not clash anymore. In your example of say the playground at least two cultural norms might be clashing for a few or maybe even most people present A) be polite and sociable in company (in this case the other parents at the playground) and B) answer when somebody speaks to you (some of us feel the messages coming in on a mobile device 'have to be answered'). For some reason a lot of people give preference to answering/interacting with others via devices to communicating with other parents at playgrounds, however that does not mean all of these people have rejected norm A. They may simply find it easier, because they feel a little intimidated by others busy looking at their devices (possibly because of a third norm might be at play 'don't interrupt people when they are clearly busy'). If a critical mass feels it would actually be nicer/better/more fun to talk to the other parents it still takes at least one change agent to 'stand up' and start looking for ways to generate change whether this is on the playground or within an organisation. Sometimes change happens over night, however that usually takes a dramatic incident, like a colleague who died because safety measure are routinely not applied (norm A being imposed by the company 'the safety rules have to be applied' and norm B being 'I can bend the rules when I think it is safe enough, the company does not need to prescribe every move I make'). In my opinion, organisational culture is an important set of beliefs, rules (implied and/or written) and practices that smoothly assists in the organisation's daily operations and are either formally or informally adopted by the participants. S Culture is not a fixed, written-in-stone and inflexible set of commandments but rather it is flexible and constantly evolving to meet the needs of the organisation's participants. Is it easy to change? That really depends on the participants' resistance to change, as well as the direction, consequence and effort required of the proposed change. From a leadership perspective the successful implementation of ‘change’ is seen as an essential mechanism that closes the gap between thought and action and strategy and implementation. The critical adjustments made by the organisation to organisational structure, operations and processes are all carried out in order to align the business activities to the market, as well as among other considerations to support the need to successfully implement strategy, improve efficiency, and secure investor returns. Hi David, you have said a lot in the above and it struck a nerve. I would like to try to respond while also formulating why it is so difficult to change organisational culture in my opinion. In my view we are all learning how to deal with all these new forms of technology and my guess is that in the future several 'types of culture' will develop in how (and when) we will use the communication technology available to us for instance in organisations and also in various social settings. These cultures may vary hugely though from one playground to the next, and certainly from one organisation to the next. For any culture to change it often takes a clash between at least two underlying norms, and it takes one or more change agents (people) that take action to remedy the clash. Three things might be the outcome when norms clash: norm A is rejected and norm B prevails; norm B is rejected and norm A prevails; or norm C (a new norm) develops somehow incorporating the two cultural norms so they do not clash anymore. In your example of say the playground at least two cultural norms might be clashing for a few or maybe even most people present A) be polite and sociable in company (in this case the other parents at the playground) and B) answer when somebody speaks to you (some of us feel the messages coming in on a mobile device 'have to be answered'). For some reason a lot of people give preference to answering/interacting with others via devices to communicating with other parents at playgrounds, however that does not mean all of these people have rejected norm A. They may simply find it easier, because they feel a little intimidated by others busy looking at their devices (possibly because of a third norm might be at play 'don't interrupt people when they are clearly busy'). If a critical mass feels it would actually be nicer/better/more fun to talk to the other parents it still takes at least one change agent to 'stand up' and start looking for ways to generate change whether this is on the playground or within an organisation. Sometimes change happens over night, however that usually takes a dramatic incident, like a colleague who died because safety measure are routinely not applied (norm A being imposed by the company 'the safety rules have to be applied' and norm B being 'I can bend the rules when I think it is safe enough, the company does not need to prescribe every move I make'). In such a case one or more change agents might 'stand up' and then the 'safety culture' might change overnight to the company rules. In most cases however the situation is similar to your example at the playground, it takes at least one parent who decides to make an effort to talk to other parents (or come up with a plan of organised change, however that is probably unlikely at the playground). Gradually more and more parents might start following that example, however some parents will resist or even be rude when someone interrupts them. If that first change agent 'fails' at the first attempt or two, they might give up trying. And for some reason a lot people simply do not want to be change agents as they are afraid of what others might think of them so they might not jump up and help the change agent right away. In short, unless there is a dramatic incident (like the death mentioned or the invention of internet 2.0) generating change often takes hard work and dealing with resistance (and a lot of guts and a bit of charisma will certainly help). And then like mentioned in the lecture, the outcome of an effort to change things might be very different from what you expected. The only thing I know for sure is that if you want change, you need to act and except that you might fail trying.

S Culture is not a fixed, written-in-stone and inflexible set of commandments but rather it is flexible and constantly evolving to meet the needs of the organisation's participants. Is it easy to change? That really depends on the participants' resistance to change, as well as the direction, consequence and effort required of the proposed change. They do so if only to adapt and respond to what is happening across their industry environments. From a leadership perspective the successful implementation of ‘change’ is seen as an essential mechanism that closes the gap between thought and action and strategy and implementation. The critical adjustments made by the organisation to organisational structure, operations and processes are all carried out in order to align the business activities to the market, as well as among other considerations to support the need to successfully implement strategy, improve efficiency, and secure investor returns. In order for such ambitions to be reached there is the crucial issue of perception to consider. Leadership perceptions are known to impact on employee behaviour in both a positive and negative manner, and thus can influence and determine the culture of the organisation. Perceptions also impact on the strategy-making process, seen by the weight of consideration and importance that leadership place on potential strategic ambitions. It therefore comes as no surprise that the individual and collective perceptions fostered by senior executives do have a significant impact on how the organisational change process is managed, and what the final outcome will look like. In addition to leadership perception, we also need to look closely at available leadership competency. Competency here refers to the characteristics and measurable patterns of behaviour, knowledge, situation awareness and skill that leadership can contribute and deliver to the organisation change process. The available breadth and depth of executive competency will determine the height of the ‘barrier of complexity ’ that routinely needs to be scaled by the company executives and staff in order to manage the change management programme to a satisfactory conclusion as well as dictating the pace at which the change progress can be implemented.

Hi Aleksei, First, we need to define what is organisational culture. In my opinion, organisational culture is an important set of beliefs, rules (implied and/or written) and practices that smoothly assists in the organisation's daily operations and are either formally or informally adopted by the participants. The organisation establishes its culture through mutual agreements that those rules, beliefs and practices are beneficial, effective and crucial, and as such the culture is deeply ingrained within the organisation and its participants. Organisational culture can be said to be the way of living and working in the organisation and hence, changing it might induce unnecessary disruption to the daily lives and operations. An example of Organisational Culture could be its belief of contributing back to society via volunteerism or caring for the environment by adopting green measures. S Culture is not a fixed, written-in-stone and inflexible set of commandments but rather it is flexible and constantly evolving to meet the needs of the organisation's participants. Is it easy to change? That really depends on the participants' resistance to change, as well as the direction, consequence and effort required of the proposed change. Changes to the culture could be introduced if the head of the organisation changes (to provide a different direction according to his/her beliefs) or when participants provided well-described, explained and irrefutable proposals for the new change. Alternatively, pressures from the external environment or even within the organisation could force the organisation to review and revise its culture. It should be noted that organisational culture should not be confused with corporate social responsibility, in which the latter comes under the former. Some organisations may or not practice corporate social responsibility depending on their size, nature and culture. And, according to my experience, corporate social responsibility activities are often the product of public relations efforts. Hence, positive organisational culture is a tool employed to do good and reap the benefits for both internal and external parties. If you are asking for an organisation to do good for others at its own expense without it reaping any form of tangible or intangible rewards (monetary or improvement to image), the organisation is most likely be unwilling to participate and the enthusiastic participant(s) might have to engage in the activity alone without the resources and support from the organisation. Organisations want to do good for others and itself too.

From a leadership perspective the successful implementation of ‘change’ is seen as an essential mechanism that closes the gap between thought and action and strategy and implementation. The critical adjustments made by the organisation to organisational structure, operations and processes are all carried out in order to align the business activities to the market, as well as among other considerations to support the need to successfully implement strategy, improve efficiency, and secure investor returns. Leadership perceptions are known to impact on employee behaviour in both a positive and negative manner, and thus can influence and determine the culture of the organisation. Competency here refers to the characteristics and measurable patterns of behaviour, knowledge, situation awareness and skill that leadership can contribute and deliver to the organisation change process. Are managers born or are they developed in an organization? Can we really make good managers?
Upvotes:
2
basically there is a difference between leaders and managers. The distinction between a 'leader' and a 'manager', both of whom may possess many of these traits, is whether people will follow the leader even if he or she is without the power of formal position. Managers may have title and authority over work to be performed by employees, but this authority and responsibility does not mean that a manager can inspire and motivate people to perform. Workers do what the manager says because they have to. People follow the instructions of leaders because they want to. Of course, every manager should also aspire to be a leader and many managers are. so yes,managers can be developed.

Anyone can become a manager simply by being placed in that role and being given a job title that includes 'manager'. I think the more important question would be: Is a leader born or can someone be developed in to a leader? My opinion on this is that some people have inherent leadership traits and abilities, but everyone can learn to be a better leader if they are willing to put in the work. This is not to say that everyone has the ability to be an amazing leader, but everyone has the potential to increase their leadership abilities.

Input.threadtitle: What is the biggest Organizational problem you have experienced?
Input.posts:
I have worked in many organizations across many sizes and sectors. However the biggest Organizational problem I have been involved with was trying to move from a strict top down (Rational) structure which had strong ties to the Military to a more open and Natural one, when the majority of the participants both current and the intake were deeply ingrained with the former. This was further complicated as the companies USP in its market place was its Military connection heritage. Would love to hear story

i am working in a tech start-up now. the biggest organizational problem I am having now is that we don't have a clear organizational structure. e.g. don't know who to report to, what is the minimum responsibilities. I think this happens to a lot of start-ups.

Hello, Jesse - Yes, I have noticed this problem in a few of the companies where I've worked, and none of those were start-ups. I think in my experience that, during times of great change, the HR department/person is not utilized properly nor given enough input power. However, company start-ups and big changes in established companies have many similarities, thus often suffer the same pitfalls. Again - utilizing change consultants and/or having a strong HR person/dept. can be extremely helpful in these situations.

The biggest organization problem that I see is when the firm/org is in a growing environment and there is a huge gap between the employees who joined when the firm/org was a start up and the employees who joined during the growing phase of the firm. In other words, a problem of tenured employees and new employees, where tenured employees assume themselves to be more powerful than the ones who joined in later is a typical organization problem witnessed in a growing organization. Is there a way to manage this problem?

Dear Soumen; This situation sounds to me like a clash between 'old school' rational organisation and newer views on opening up the structure to allow for growth and ingenuity. And, yes, I agree it could be a demotivator for those who see themselves as 'on top,' or powerful. However, it would seem to me that possibly those who are present from the lower ranks or the less powerful positions would really engage with this process and be more motivated. In business, there is a Darwinism that prevails and possibly should do in a case where management is busy spending time belly-aching rather than problem-solving.

Reflecting on this thread there are many themes that are brought up around common or the biggest organisational issues facing companies today. I would like to list a broader spectrum of challenges to encourage more participation and discussion. Here is a list of what I think are challenges facing many companies driven by factors like greater competition, technology, regulation and speed to market: More complexity - harder to make decisions Ambiguous structures - traditional, matrix, hybrids and loose coupling Gender, generational and demographic diversity - four generations working side by side, more women in the workforce, more part-time people working Proliferation of connectivity devices - Bring your own devices, smart phones and tablets making work easier and more complex at the same time Performance evaluation systems - where they occur there seems to be a problem with motivating people and possibly encouraging employees to adopt poor behaviours] Open office environment - does it really work for all companies, it may encourage collaboration but not all companies work 100% of the time in this mode and people still need to produce individual deliverables etc. etc. These are just a few that impact on how we organise, coordinate work and behave in companies. Identify the themes that are applicable to you in your situation - this will help you better understand the theories that will be discussed in this course and provide some further tools to potentially minimise the negative effects. In my experience it is hard to find organisations that are perfect, they are always a work in progress towards a constantly changing end-game, but those entities that have the capability to self diagnose and address shortfalls tend to be on average more successful.

Input.threadtitle: Need Help: How to implement company culture in a start-up company？
Input.posts:
Dear All, I have taken a hard task: implementation org. culture in a start-up company. The content and key words of org. culture is done by the leadership team via discussions. But how to make management team and all employees to buy-in the org. culture? How to make the culture into daily work of every employee? I have no idea. Btw, the employees are very young with 27 years old average, in the fast development. More and more new hires are coming. Now, we have about 400 employees. Do you have any ideas or experiences, proposal to help me? Thanks a lot.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Interesting topic. If this is a start up, I assume that this organization is brand new? My advice is to start with what you know. Use ambiguity to your advantage with discussion via the leadership team then build it from there. Perhaps you could create some type of document to guide 'Logic of Appropriateness' within the company in a culture or social sense if collaboration and civility are required. Depending on what the company does, it may be a good idea to canvas other similar organizations to see what they do and find 'best practices', in order to build 'legitimacy'. You can also find the people who serve as 'hubs' and 'bridges' in order to build your culture. You may also want to consider if 'culture' is what you really want. There is also organizational learning. 400 employees is a lot of people to influence. Good luck.
